instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.RTC_RESET_L: What is RTC_RESET_L? RTC_RESET_L is a reset signal that is present when the signal is low, the _L means it is asserted when the voltage is low. The RESET signal will keep the PCH from turning on or booting up the machine. .
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..
definitions.PCH_INTRUDER_L: What is PCH_INTRUDER_L? PCH_INTRUDER_L is a signal that tells the machine the case has been opened by an intruder when it is low, the _L means it is present when it is low. This signal should always be high in a Macbook since it doesnâ€™t use intrusion detection. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Got 20V Back, Still No Power
threads.message: Got this board here which was previously poked by another assistance. It got liquid damage(was cleaned before) and had no 20V. Replaced <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> and SMC and got 20V back, but still no power. Compared side by side with another board from same model and cannot find any missing components. It does not pull any current from wall charger. Could not find any shorts to GND. <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> stable 13V, board does not pass S5, stuck in S5.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Got 20V Back, Still No Power
threads.message:
Check PCH's RTC signals.
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Got 20V Back, Still No Power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP3V1_RTC</SIGNAL> - 3.1V
<SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL> - 3.1V
<SIGNAL>PPDCPRTC_PCH</SIGNAL> - 1.1V
<SIGNAL>RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> - 3.1V

For <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> I don't know if I understood well, but I tried to short it to and while measuring <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> signal and <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> did not get any pulses... It's steady 3.3V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Got 20V Back, Still No Power
threads.message:
You must make temporary short, like pressing power button.
And check <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> reaction at the same time!
Do not keep <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> tied to ground.

What about <SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Got 20V Back, Still No Power
threads.message: Was what I did. I shorted <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> to GND with the tips of tweezers while measuring <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> and it didn't chance. Will check <SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Got 20V Back, Still No Power
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Got 20V Back, Still No Power
threads.message:
Solder an wire on <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and tocuh any metal plate when you want to trigger it; more easy than using tweezer.

You may need to reball <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> too.
Did you take SMC from the same board model?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Got 20V Back, Still No Power
threads.message: Yes, SMC is from same model. Will recall <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> tomorrow and post results.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Got 20V Back, Still No Power
threads.message: First I tried replacing the PMIC and I lost <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> line. Then I reballed original chip and put it back. Got back <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> but still no power draw

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Got 20V Back, Still No Power
threads.message:
Check <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>.
Do you have correct/original charger for this machine?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Got 20V Back, Still No Power
threads.message: I tried replacing SMC again, took it from a donor board where I know SMC is working(the one I was trying to fix some days ago which got dead CPU), now I don't have 20V anymore. And yes, original 96W Apple charger with original cable. Will try putting back the other SMC again and check <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Got 20V Back, Still No Power
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Got 20V Back, Still No Power
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Got 20V Back, Still No Power
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Got 20V Back, Still No Power
threads.message:
Diode mode to ground there?
Check <SIGNAL>PM_EN_P3V3S5G</SIGNAL> presence.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Got 20V Back, Still No Power
threads.message:
Diode mode to GND on <SIGNAL>3V3_S5G</SIGNAL> - 0.322

No enable signal. Also, <SIGNAL>PMIC_PGE</SIGNAL> signal is missing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Got 20V Back, Still No Power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> is controlled by SMC, but PCH can block it, if has an internal problem.

<SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> goes high?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Got 20V Back, Still No Power
